title: How I Would Think About Money If I Had 10 Years Left to Live
subtitle: Key reflections on spending and prioritization when time is limited.
content:
How I Would Think About Money If I Had 10 Years Left to Live

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. If any of this is helpful, check out my new podcast, Your Money Guide on the Side, by clicking the link in my bio.

1. Prioritize Physical Activity

Knowing that the average American hits their physical peak in their 30s, cognitive peak in their 40s, and orthopedic peak right before rotator cuff surgery in their 50s, I’d prioritize spending on real physical activity right now.

2. Stop Saving for an Illusionary Future

I'd stop saving for the future like it’s some magical era where time slows down and my hips stop hurting. Newsflash: your future self also has access to email. It won't wait for you!

3. Balance Cash and Time Wisely

Most people are time-rich when they're broke and cash-rich when they're exhausted. That’s not a financial plan; that’s a scheduling error. If you only had 10 summers left, how would you spend this one? Good. Now go do that right now because it's summertime!
